raw_text:
FA decides not to punish Mourinho
 
 The Football Association will take no action against Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho following his sending-off in Sunday's Carling Cup final.
 
 Mourinho, who was sent from the touchline for appearing to taunt Liverpool fans, has been "reminded of his responsibilities to the game". But the FA confirmed: "There will be no further action taken in this matter." Mourinho claimed his 'silence' gesture was aimed at the media, although they were on the other side of the ground. The former Porto coach was forced to watch the climax of his side's 3-2 victory over Liverpool on television after being ushered away from the touchline by fourth official Phil Crossley. His gesture came after Chelsea's equaliser on 79 minutes courtesy of a Steven Gerrard own goal. Mourinho still faces an FA investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's players 'cheated' during January's Carling Cup semi-final at Stamford Bridge.
 
 And Uefa could also launch disciplinary action following Mourinho's failure to attend a compulsory post-match press conference after Chelsea's Champions League defeat at Barcelona last week. In addition, some time this month, Chelsea must also answer a charge of failing to control their players during the Premiership win at Blackburn in February. And a charge of failing to control their supporters following a Carling Cup meeting with West Ham earlier this season is still to be heard. The Premier League is also continuing investigations into allegations Chelsea officials tapped up Arsenal defender Ashley Cole in January.
llama3.2:1b: The FA will not take action against Jose Mourinho due to his sending-off for taunting Liverpool fans during the Carling Cup final.
llama3.2:3b: The Football Association will not take action against Jose Mourinho for his sending-off in the Carling Cup final, but he faces FA investigations over other incidents, including an allegation that Manchester United cheated during a semi-final match and failing to attend a post-match press conference after a Champions League defeat. Chelsea also faces charges related to controlling players and supporters at two separate matches and is under investigation for allegedly tapping up Arsenal's Ashley Cole in January.
gemma2:2b: The FA will not take action against Jose Mourinho for his sending-off during the Carling Cup final.  He faces separate investigations from UEFA and the Premier League regarding his behavior, as well as charges related to player conduct and supporter misconduct.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Football Association does not take any further action against Jose Mourinho because he was given a 'silence' gesture during the Carling Cup final, which came after his fans taunted him for allegedly helping Manchester United cheat. The FA has confirmed that "there will be no further action taken in this matter."
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Football Association will not punish Jose Mourinho for his behavior during the Liverpool match, citing responsibilities to the game and no further action. Mourinho faces ongoing disciplinary actions regarding alleged cheating accusations and failure to control players/fans post-game matches.
qwen2.5:3b: The Football Association (FA) has decided not to punish Jose Mourinho, who was sent off during the Carling Cup final for taunting Liverpool fans. Despite claiming his gesture was directed at the media, Mourinho will face an FA investigation over claims Manchester United 'cheated' during a previous match. Additionally, Chelsea is still facing disciplinary action from UEFA for Mourinho's failure to attend a post-match press conference after their Champions League loss and failing to control players during a Premiership win. The club also has pending charges of not controlling supporters and tapping up Arsenal player Ashley Cole.
opencoder:1.5b: The Football Association will take no action against Jose Mourinho following his sending-off in Sunday's Carling Cup final, Mourinho has been reminded of his responsibilities to the game but there will be no further action taken in this matter and he still faces an FA investigation into his allegation.
smollm:1.7b: The FA decides not to punish Mourinho for sending-off Chelsea boss in Sunday's Carling Cup final. There will be no further action taken in this matter. Mourinho claimed his "silence" gesture was aimed at the media, although they were on the other side of the ground. The former Porto coach was forced to watch the climax of his side's 3-2 victory over Liverpool on television after being ushered away from the touchline by fourth official Phil Crossley. Mourinho still faces an FA investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's players 'cheated' during January's Carling Cup semi-final at Stamford Bridge.

Okay, I need to help the user by summarizing a given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. Let me read through the provided text carefully.

First, the main points are about the Football Association's decision regarding Mourinho. The FA decided not to punish Mourinho after his appearance at the Carling Cup final. Mourinho was sent off due to taunting, and he was reminded of his responsibilities. However, there's no further action taken by the FA. 

Additionally, there are some details that mention Mourinho facing disciplinary actions by both Uefa and the Premier League for not attending press conferences after specific losses. Chelsea has also faced a charge related to a player they allegedly cheated.

So, I should focus on preserving these key elements: the FA's stance on Mourinho, the potential disciplinary action from Uefa, and the possible actions from the Premier League. I'll make sure to keep it plain text without explanations or formatting.
</think>

The Football Association has decided not to punish Jose Mourinho after his appearance in Sunday's Carling Cup final. Mourinho was reminded of his responsibilities following his appearance at the event, but no further action was taken by the FA. Mourinho faces disciplinary action from Uefa and the Premier League for failing to attend press conferences following specific losses. Chelsea has also faced allegations related to a player they allegedly cheated.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Football Association has decided not to take any further action against Jose Mourinho after his sending-off during the Carling Cup final match between Liverpool and Chelsea. Mourirno's "silence" gesture was aimed at the media, but he faced being ushered away from the touchline by fourth official Phil Crossley following his equalizer on 79 minutes. The former Porto coach is still facing an FA investigation into his allegations of cheating, including a possible charge of failing to attend a compulsory press conference and time for a hearing in relation to a match-fixing case. Mourirno must also answer charges that he failed to control his players during Blackburn's 2-1 win over Chelsea earlier this season, as well as a charge of failure to control supporters following West Ham's defeat at Stamford Bridge earlier this year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: FA's decision not to punish Jose Mourinho, who was sent off in the Carling Cup final after taunting Liverpool fans, comes after they reminded him of his responsibilities to the game. This suggests that there is no indication of any further action being taken by the Football Association against Mourinho. Mourinho's actions were seen as a public statement aimed at the media, and though they were on the opposing team's side during the match, they did not follow the process laid down in their disciplinary code. This could potentially lead to further FA investigations, with the possibility of disciplinary action being taken against Mourinho or his club, Chelsea.

Mourinho claims his 'silence' gesture was aimed at the media, but there won't be any further investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's players cheated during the January's Carling Cup semi-final. Mourinho also failed to attend a compulsory press conference after Chelsea's defeat at Barcelona and Chelsea must answer charges of failing to control their supporters and their players. FA is also continuing investigations into allegations of Cole being tapped up by Arsenal in January.

hermes3:3b: FA not punishing Mourinho after sending-off in Carling Cup final.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Football Association (FA) decided not to punish Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho for his sending-off during the Carling Cup final, as he was "reminded of his responsibilities to the game." Mourinho's gesture, which appeared to taunt Liverpool fans, led to his removal from the touchline. However, no further action will be taken by the FA. The former Porto coach still faces an ongoing investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's players cheated during January's Carling Cup semi-final. Additionally, UEFA could launch disciplinary action due to Mourinho's absence from a compulsory post-match press conference after Chelsea's Champions League defeat against Barcelona. Furthermore, Chelsea is facing charges for failing to control their players and supporters in various matches throughout the season.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The Football Association (FA) has decided not to punish Jose Mourinino, the Chelsea manager, for his sending-off during Sunday's Carling Cup final due to his "taunting" of Liverpool fans. The FA reminded Mourinho of his responsibilities but found no further action necessary. This incident occurred after Chelsea's equalizer by Steven Gerrard, leading to 3-2 victory. However, Mourinino still faces separate investigations: an FA inquiry into allegations of Manchester United players cheating during a previous match and potential Uefa disciplinary action for his non-attendance at a post-match press conference after Chelsea's Champions League loss to Barcelona. Additionally, Chelsea is under investigation for failing to control their players in a Premiership game against Blackburn and for supporter misconduct during a Carling Cup tie with West Ham. The Premier League also continues probing claims of Chelsea officials approaching Arsenal's Ashley Cole in January.
reference: The Football Association will take no action against Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho following his sending-off in Sunday's Carling Cup final.Mourinho still faces an FA investigation into his allegation that Manchester United's players 'cheated' during January's Carling Cup semi-final at Stamford Bridge.And a charge of failing to control their supporters following a Carling Cup meeting with West Ham earlier this season is still to be heard.Mourinho claimed his 'silence' gesture was aimed at the media, although they were on the other side of the ground.Mourinho, who was sent from the touchline for appearing to taunt Liverpool fans, has been "reminded of his responsibilities to the game".
